content:
When making lending decisions for startup companies, lenders typically consider a number of factors, including:

1. Creditworthiness of the founders: Lenders will often look at the credit history and credit score of the founders to assess their ability to repay the loan.
2. Business Plan: Lenders will review the company's business plan to ensure that it is viable, and to understand the company's revenue and cash flow projections.
3. Revenue and Cash Flow: Lenders will look at the company's current revenue and cash flow to assess its ability to repay the loan.
4. Collateral: Lenders will look for assets that the company can use as collateral, such as property, equipment, or inventory.
5. Industry and Market: Lenders will consider the company's industry and market to assess its potential for growth and profitability.
6. First-time Jobbers: Lenders may also consider the employment history of the founders, and give more weight to those who have experience in the industry they are starting up in.

It's worth noting that the lending decision process may vary depending on the type of loan and the lender. Some lenders may place more emphasis on certain factors than others. Additionally, some lenders may be more willing to take on risk than others, so the lending criteria may be different for different lenders.
